message.content:
Search for ways to programmatically import FCP XML or media into Premiere Pro.

Look for:
1. UXP API methods for importing media or XML files
2. Project.importFiles() or similar methods
3. Any method to import FCP XML as a sequence
4. File system triggers that could auto-import files

Check the official Adobe documentation and any code samples.

Based on my search, here's what I found about UXP API, Premiere Pro, and importing FCP XML media files:

## UXP API for Premiere Pro

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)Premiere APIs, also called DOM APIs, give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects (sequences, tracks, clips, and markers), work with media (import files, manage project items), control playback, and apply effects.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls were synchronous and blocked the UI. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.

## Importing FCP XML into Premiere Pro

Final Cut Pro X exports a .fcpxml file, which Premiere Pro does not recognize. To bring an FCP X file into Premiere Pro, you need a converter tool that converts the .fcpxml file into a standard .xml file. Adobe recommends using the XtoCC tool for this conversion.

For Final Cut Pro 7 XML files:
In Premiere Pro, select File > Import, browse to the XML file, and click Open.

## Key Compatibility Notes

The format of XML that Premiere uses is different from that of FCP, and needs to be converted before it can be imported. The third party application SendToX can do that.(no content)FCP X and Premiere use different versions of XML, so conversion is required. XtoCC is available in the Mac App Store for $49.99.(no content)Compound clips are translated as nested sequences. However, the destination app importing Final Cut Pro 7 XML may not necessarily support nested sequences, such as Adobe Audition and After Effects. You can avoid this by breaking apart compound clips in a project into their original items.

## What Gets Transferred

In Premiere Pro, bins and clips have the same hierarchies and names that they have in the Final Cut Pro source projects. Premiere Pro retains sequence markers, sequence settings, track layout, locked tracks, and sequence timecode start points. It also imports text from Final Cut Pro Text generators into Premiere Pro titles.

If you're looking to programmatically import FCP XML files using the UXP API, the search results don't show a specific UXP method for importing FCP XML directly. You would likely need to use the standard file import functionality through the Premiere DOM API.

Based on my search results, I can provide you with information about the Premiere Pro UXP `Project.importFiles()` method documentation. Here's what I found:

## Premiere Pro UXP API - Project Methods

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### ExtendScript `importFiles()` Method (Legacy)

The documentation found relates primarily to the **ExtendScript API** (the older scripting system):

`app.project.importFiles(filePaths, suppressUI, targetBin, importAsNumberedStills)` imports media from the specified file paths. Returns true if successful, false if not.

### UXP API - Project Class

For the newer UXP-based API, the official documentation at `developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/project/` shows:

The Project class includes static methods like `createProject` (to create a new project) and `getActiveProject` (to get the currently active project).(no content)Other available properties/methods include the root item of the project which contains all items of the project on the lowest level, and the ability to get an array of all sequences in this project.

### Important Notes About UXP API

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.(no content)For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited. It is worth noting that they are, in the background, asynchronous in nature.

### Resources

The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/

Based on my search, **the `importFiles()` method does not appear to be explicitly documented in the current UXP API reference**. The method exists in the older ExtendScript API, but the UXP API for Premiere Pro is still evolving. You may want to check the official documentation directly at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/project/ for the most up-to-date list of available methods, or consult the Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums for specific import functionality in UXP.

Based on my search, here's what I found about UXP Premiere Pro and the importFiles/importSequences methods for importing media and XML:

## UXP in Premiere Pro

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## Import Methods in UXP

### importFiles()
The `importFiles` method has the following signature:
`importFiles(filePaths: string[], suppressUI?: boolean, targetBin?: ProjectItem, asNumberedStills?: boolean): Promise<boolean>` - Import files in root/target bin of the project.(no content)The method `app.project.importFiles(filePaths, suppressUI, targetBin, importAsNumberedStills)` imports media from the specified file paths. Returns true if successful, false if not.

### importSequences()
The `importSequences` method has the signature: `importSequences(projectPath: string, sequenceIds?: Guid[]): Promise<boolean>`(no content)This method imports an array of sequence objects (with specified sequenceIDs), from the specified project, into the current project. Returns 0 if successful.

## Key Differences from ExtendScript

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread.

## Working with Media

Premiere APIs (also called DOM APIs) give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you work with media — import files, manage project items, access and modify projects (sequences, tracks, clips, and markers), control playback, and apply effects.

## XML Import Note

Regarding XML import: Premiere Pro stores metadata that helps it determine which files exist in a project, however when roundtripping via XML through a non-Adobe app this metadata can get lost, resulting in Premiere duplicating all of the existing media in the project upon import.

## Getting Started

To build UXP plugins, you need Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later.(no content)To access the Premiere DOM via UXP, you can use the require statement to get access. From there, you can open documents, modify them, run menu items, and more.

Based on my search results, here's what I found regarding UXP, Premiere Pro, file system, watch, trigger, import, and monitoring:

## UXP in Premiere Pro

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize the most precise, demanding workflows.

### File System and Core Functionality

UXP provides file system, networking, shell execution, and core UXP functionality.(no content)UXP Core APIs are for building user interfaces, file operations, network calls, and general functionality. Premiere APIs are for interacting with and modifying Premiere projects and sequences. Most often than not, you will need to use both APIs together to create the functionality you want.

### Watch & Reload for Development

The UXP Developer Tool has a shortcut for the Load and Watch actions. The plugin will be loaded in Premiere, and UDT will watch for changes in the plugin's source code and reload it automatically.

However, some developers recommend only using "Load" and not "Load and Watch" feature. The built-in UDT file watcher aka "Load and Watch" does not reliably update on changes. Alternative solutions like Bolt UXP come with built-in WebSocket systems to trigger a reload on each update which is more consistent and less error-prone.

### Import Functionality

The Premiere Pro UXP API includes an `importFiles` function that accepts parameters for file paths, suppressUI, targetBin, and asNumberedStills, returning a Promise.(no content)The Source monitor API allows you to retrieve the project item corresponding to the media open in the Source monitor, open a file in the Source monitor (returning true if successful), and open a project item in the Source monitor.

### Current Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a constantly growing set of applications, including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.

The search results don't show a specific built-in file system watcher that automatically triggers imports when files are added to a monitored folder. Such functionality would likely need to be built as a custom UXP plugin using the file system APIs combined with the import APIs.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro, UXP, importFiles, XML, and FCPXML limitations:

## Key Findings

### XML Format Incompatibility Between Premiere Pro and Final Cut Pro

"We can't open XML out of Premiere Pro directly in Final Cut Pro X, or vice versa. They, literally, do not speak the same language."(no content)There are two types of XML to consider: xmeml (used by Premiere Pro) and fcpxml (used by Final Cut Pro X).

### Premiere Pro's FCPXML Limitations

Final Cut Pro X exports a .fcpxml file, which Premiere Pro does not recognize.(no content)To bring in an FCP X file into Premiere Pro, you need a converter tool that converts the .fcpxml file into a standard .xml file that Premiere Pro can import. Adobe recommends using the XtoCC tool for this conversion.(no content)Since version 1.8, Final Cut Pro has changed from exporting .xml files that used to be capable of being imported into Premiere Pro CC to what is now .fcpxml that Premiere Pro CC cannot import.(no content)Premiere does not read .fcpxml files from FCPX, but it does read .xml files from FCP7.

### Version Compatibility Issues

Final Cut Pro X version 10.2 can open version 1.5 of fcpxml, but it cannot open version 1.6 from 10.3. Final Cut Pro X 10.3 allows saving as version 1.5 XML for this reason, and opens older versions of fcpxml.(no content)Premiere creates "legacy Final Cut Pro (i.e. version 7 or earlier) XML. And of course this has been eol'ed more than ten years ago."

### Workarounds

From Premiere Pro, export an XML of the main sequence. Then use SendToX from Intelligent Assistance to convert Premiere's XML format into FCP's FCPXML format. Then import the new FCPXML into a Final Cut Pro event.(no content)A free workaround requires the lite version of DaVinci Resolve. Import the fcpxml into Resolve, export from Resolve to AAF, then import the AAF into Premiere Pro. There may be a little cleaning up to do but it's the best workaround.(no content)Not all elements of a Final Cut Pro X project get imported into Premiere Pro.(no content)Some things may or may not translate correctly between the formats.

Note: The search results focused on general XML/FCPXML import limitations in Premiere Pro but did not return specific information about UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) and the `importFiles` API method specifically. If you need more details about UXP scripting limitations for importing XML files programmatically, I can perform an additional search focusing on that aspect.

Based on my search, I found information about the `importFiles` method in the AdobeDocs uxp-premiere-pro repository. Here's what I discovered:

## importFiles API in UXP for Premiere Pro

The `importFiles` method has the following TypeScript signature:
```typescript
importFiles(filePaths: string[], suppressUI?: boolean, targetBin?: ProjectItem, asNumberedStills?: boolean): Promise<boolean>
```
This method imports files into the root or target bin of the project.

### Parameters:
- **filePaths** (string[]): Array of file paths to import
- **suppressUI** (boolean, optional): Whether to suppress the UI during import
- **targetBin** (ProjectItem, optional): The target bin/folder to import files into
- **asNumberedStills** (boolean, optional): Whether to import as numbered stills

### Return Value:
- Returns a `Promise<boolean>` indicating success or failure

## Related Resources

The AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples repository contains instructions for developing UXP plugins within Premiere Pro. As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/(no content)As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. If you are starting new development, you should start in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported, with plans to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year before removing CEP extensibility support.

### Key GitHub Repositories:
- **Documentation**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro
- **Samples**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples
- **TypeScript definitions**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts

Based on the search results, here's the information about Premiere Pro UXP import media file functionality:

## Premiere Pro UXP Import Media File

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)UXP is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications, powered by a modern JavaScript engine that offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### Import Files API

The `importFiles` method takes the following parameters:
- `filePaths: string[]` - Array of file paths to import
- `suppressUI?: boolean` (optional) - Whether to suppress UI dialogs

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP file system API and watching folders for changes in Premiere Pro:

## UXP File System API in Premiere Pro

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

### UXP Core APIs

There are two main API types: UXP Core APIs for building user interfaces, file operations, network calls, and general functionality; and Premiere APIs for interacting with and modifying Premiere projects and sequences.(no content)The UXP Core APIs include file system, networking, shell execution, and core UXP functionality.(no content)UXP Core APIs provide the fundamental building blocks for your plugin's functionality and are shared across all Adobe Creative Cloud applications that support UXP.

### Accessing APIs

Module-based APIs require importing with `require()`. Permission-based APIs also need to be allow-listed in your plugin's manifest.json.

### Version Information

Premiere version (v25.6) determines which Premiere DOM APIs are available, while UXP version (v8.1) determines which UXP Core APIs are available. Each Premiere release integrates a specific UXP version—for example, Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.

### Watch Folder Monitoring

The search results did not return specific documentation about a **watch folder** or **file monitoring** API within UXP for Premiere Pro. The UXP Developer Tool does have a "Load and Watch" feature, but this watches for changes in the plugin's source code and reloads it automatically rather than monitoring arbitrary folders.

For specific file system watching capabilities, you may need to:
1. Check the detailed UXP Core API documentation for any `fs.watch()` equivalent
2. Visit the official documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
3. Consider using polling-based approaches to check for file changes if native watching isn't supported

The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

Based on my search, here's what I found about UXP file system permissions, access restrictions, and limitations:

## UXP File System Permissions and Restrictions

### Sandboxing Requirements
Because of sandboxing requirements of recent OS releases, UXP does not allow arbitrary access to any file on the host system.(no content)Therefore, files external to the plugin are accessed by making a request of the user (by showing a file-picker dialog) and obtaining a token.

### Default Access Levels
The localFileSystem permission controls access to the user's local file system. If not specified, the plugin has no access to the user's file system other than the default access to plugin://, plugin-temp://, and plugin-data://.

### Permission Levels
localFileSystem accepts:
- **request**: Allows the plugin to access the local file system using pickers for opening and saving files.
- **plugin**: Allows the plugin to access the plugin's storage only.
- **fullAccess**: Allows the plugin to inspect, modify, and delete files to which you have access on all volumes attached to this device. The user will be required to consent before installation or update.

### OS-Level Limitations
Despite the manifest setting fullAccess, certain files and folders may still not be accessible. It depends on the permission of the Operating System.

### Token-Based Access
A persistent token is useful for storing a persistent reference to an entry (if you want to only ask for permission to access a file or folder once). However, a persistent token is not guaranteed to last forever – certain scenarios can cause the token to longer work (including moving files, changing permissions, or OS-specific limitations). If a persistent token cannot be reused, you'll get an error at the time of use.

### Handling Invalid Tokens
Retrieving an entry for a persistent token does not guarantee that the entry is valid for use. You'll need to properly handle the case where the entry no longer exists on the disk, or the permissions have changed by catching the appropriate errors. If that occurs, the suggested practice is to prompt the user for the entry again and store the new token.

### Plugin Storage Locations
UXP provides a shorthand representation of locations via schemes. For sandbox, you can use plugin:/, plugin-data:/, and plugin-temp:/. And, for other locations, use file:/.

### Manifest Permissions Model
The UXP team takes the concepts of Users' trust and consent quite seriously. In the Manifest you declare upfront what kind of permissions your plugin needs, e.g., to open a website, read the clipboard, mess with the Filesystem, etc. Eventually, this information is going to be displayed in your plugin's CC Marketplace product page.

### Future Improvements
In the near future, UXP will provide a permissions system for persistent tokens so developers won't need user interaction for the same path every session. For now, if you need constant access to a location to write and read files, please use the UXP sanctioned locations for your plugin, accessed by the methods listed in the FileSystemProvider object of UXP.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP importSequences and XML project files:

## Premiere Pro UXP and importSequences

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### UXP API Overview

The UXP platform provides two main types of APIs: UXP Core APIs for building user interfaces, file operations, network calls, and general functionality, and Premiere APIs for interacting with and modifying Premiere projects and sequences.(no content)The Premiere UXP API allows access to sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.(no content)For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited, though they are asynchronous in the background. Through the app object, you can access the rest of Premiere's objects and methods.

### importSequences Function (ExtendScript)

The `importSequences` function exists in the ExtendScript API. When using importSequences, you need to pass an actual sequence.sequenceid rather than a sequence name. You can get the id of a sequence like: `var templateSequenceID = mytemplateSequence.sequenceid`.(no content)The correct property name is `Sequence.sequenceID` (with capitalized "ID"), which returns an ID like "2714b58d-10a0-4801-9646-8a4f6f1e2a98".

### XML Import in Premiere Pro

You can import entire projects, selected clips, or selected sequences that you export from Final Cut Pro as XML files. In Premiere Pro, bins and clips have the same hierarchies and names as in the source projects, and Premiere Pro retains sequence markers, settings, track layout, locked tracks, and timecode start points.(no content)You cannot import native Final Cut Pro project files, only XML files exported from Final Cut Pro.

### Development Resources

Instructions for developing UXP plugins within Premiere Pro are available, with the Premiere Pro UXP API documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

content.text:
## Summary: Programmatic FCP XML and Media Import to Premiere Pro

Based on my research, here's what I found regarding programmatically importing FCP XML or media into Premiere Pro:

### Key UXP API Methods

The Premiere Pro UXP API provides several import methods:

1. **importFiles() - For Media Files**
   - Signature: `importFiles(filePaths: string[], suppressUI?: boolean, targetBin?: ProjectItem, asNumberedStills?: boolean): Promise<boolean>`
   - Imports media files (audio, video, images) into the project
   - Returns Promise<boolean> indicating success/failure
   - Parameters allow suppressing UI dialogs and specifying target bins
   - Available in UXP for Premiere Pro 25.6+

2. **importSequences() - For Premiere Project Files**
   - Signature: `importSequences(projectPath: string, sequenceIds?: Guid[]): Promise<boolean>`
   - Imports sequences from another Premiere Pro project file
   - Does NOT directly import XML files or FCP projects
   - Can import specific sequences by ID

3. **importAEComps() and importAllAEComps()**
   - For importing After Effects compositions, not relevant for FCP XML

### FCP XML Limitations

Critical finding: **Premiere Pro cannot directly import Final Cut Pro X (.fcpxml) files via UXP or any native method**

- Premiere Pro only reads .xml files from Final Cut Pro 7 or earlier
- Final Cut Pro X exports .fcpxml format, which is incompatible with Premiere
- Conversion is required using third-party tools:
  - XtoCC (commercial tool, $49.99)
  - SendToX (from Intelligent Assistance)
  - Free workaround: DaVinci Resolve (import FCPXML → export AAF → import to Premiere)

### File System Access & Monitoring

**Important Limitations for UXP:**
- UXP sandboxes file system access and does NOT provide native file watching/monitoring
- Files must be accessed via user file picker dialogs for security (unless fullAccess permission granted)
- No built-in "watch folder" API for automatic imports
- File system permissions are declared in manifest.json and require user consent

### What's NOT Available

- No native importXML() or importFCP() method in UXP
- No automatic file watcher that triggers on new files
- No direct .fcpxml → sequence conversion
- File system watching would require custom polling implementation

### Practical Approach for Auto-Importing

To implement auto-importing of XML or media files, you would need to:
1. Request fullAccess or request-level file system permissions in manifest.json
2. Implement polling logic (timer-based checks) rather than native file watching
3. For FCP XML: externally convert .fcpxml to .xml using XtoCC first
4. Use importFiles() for media or importSequences() for .prproj files
5. Handle the async Promise-based API calls

Sources:
- [The Premiere UXP API](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- [Premiere API—UXP for Adobe Premiere](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/)
- [Import XML files from Final Cut Pro 7 and Final Cut Pro X](https://helpx.adobe.com/premiere-pro/using/importing-xml-project-files-final.html)
- [GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples)
- [Understanding UXP APIs](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/fundamentals/apis/)
- [File Access in UXP](https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/guides/uxp_guide/uxp-misc/file-access/)
- [How to import sequences into Premiere Pro from XML without duplicating media](https://www.digitalrebellion.com/blog/posts/how_to_import_sequences_into_premiere_pro_from_xml_without_duplicating_files)
